original: Paṭṭhānapakaraṇa
analyzed: paṭṭhāna pakaraṇa
translated: The Book of Conditional Relations🔽The Book of the Middle Length Sayings🔽The Book of the Numerical Sayings

original: Dhammānulomapaccanīya (3), Dukadukapaṭṭhānapāḷi (6)
analyzed: dhamma anuloma paccanīya
translated: The Book of the Ones🔽The Book of the Twelves

original: 18.1. Hetuduka, Sahetukaduka
analyzed: hetu duka sa hetuka duka
translated: The Book of Cause and Effect

original: Namo tassa Bhagavato Arahato Sammāsambuddhassa.
analyzed: namaḥ tassa bhagavataḥ arahataḥ sammāsambuddhassa
translated: Homage to the Blessed One, the Worthy One, the Rightly Self-awakened One.

original: Hetuṁ sahetukaṁ dhammaṁ paṭicca nahetu nasahetuko dhammo uppajjati hetupaccayā. Nahetuṁ sahetukaṁ dhammaṁ paṭicca nahetu nasahetuko dhammo uppajjati hetupaccayā.
analyzed: hetum sa hetukam dhammam paṭicca na hetu na sa hetukaḥ dhammaḥ uppajjati hetu paccayā na hetum sa hetukam dhammam paṭicca na hetu na sa hetukaḥ dhammaḥ uppajjati hetu paccayā
translated: With a cause and an effect as condition, a state without a cause and without an effect arises through a condition by way of cause. With a state without a cause and without an effect as condition, a state without a cause and without an effect arises through a condition by way of cause.

original: Hetuṁ sahetukañca nahetuṁ sahetukañca dhammaṁ paṭicca nahetu nasahetuko dhammo uppajjati hetupaccayā. (Saṅkhittaṁ.)
analyzed: hetum sa hetukam ca na hetum sa hetukañca dhammam paṭicca na hetu na sa hetukaḥ dhammaḥ uppajjati hetu paccayā
translated: With a cause and an effect and a state without a cause and without an effect as condition, a state without a cause and without an effect arises through a condition by way of cause. (In brief.)

original: Hetuyā tīṇi, ārammaṇe ekaṁ, adhipatiyā tīṇi …pe… aññamaññe pañca …pe… vipāke tīṇi …pe… avigate pañca.
analyzed: hetuyā tīṇi ārammaṇe eka adhipatiyā tīṇi pe aññamaññe pañca pe vipāke tīṇi pe avigate pañca
translated: In the case of cause, there are three; in the case of object, one; in the case of predominance, three. … In the case of mutuality, five. … In the case of kamma result, three. … In the case of dissociation, five.

original: Nahetuṁ sahetukaṁ dhammaṁ paṭicca nanahetu nasahetuko dhammo uppajjati nahetupaccayā … (Saṅkhittaṁ.)
analyzed: na hetum sa hetukam dhammam paṭicca na na hetu na sa hetukaḥ dhammaḥ uppajjati na hetu paccayā
translated: With a state without a cause and without an effect as condition, a state without a cause and without an effect arises through a condition by way of cause. … (In brief.)

original: Nahetuyā ekaṁ, naārammaṇe tīṇi, naadhipatiyā pañca, napurejāte cattāri …pe… navippayutte ekaṁ …pe… novigate tīṇi.
analyzed: na hetuyā eka na ārammaṇe tīṇi na adhipatiyā pañca na purejāte cattāri pe na vippayutte ekam pe no vigate tīṇi
translated: With non-cause as condition: one. With non-object as condition: three. With non-dominance as condition: five. With non-decisive-support as condition: four. With non-kamma as condition: four. With non-nutritive-essence as condition: four. With non-pre-nascence as condition: four. With non-priority as condition: four. With non-contiguous as condition: four. With non-dependence as condition: four. With non-source as condition: four. With non-root as condition: four. With non-sphere as condition: one. With non-path as condition: four. With non-non-causality as condition: one. With non-non-object as condition: three.

original: (Sahajātavārampi …pe… sampayuttavārampi paṭiccavārasadisaṁ.)
analyzed: sahajāta vārampi pe sampayutta vārampi paṭicca vāra sadisa
translated: (The section on origination should be elaborated in the same way as the section on condition.)

original: Hetu-ārammaṇa
analyzed: hetu ārammaṇa
translated: Cause and object

original: Hetu sahetuko dhammo nahetussa nasahetukassa dhammassa hetupaccayena paccayo.🔽Hetu sahetuko dhammo nahetussa nasahetukassa dhammassa ārammaṇapaccayena paccayo.
analyzed: hetu sa hetukaḥ dhammaḥ na hetussa na sa hetukassa dhammassa hetu paccayena paccayaḥ  hetu sa hetukaḥ dhammaḥ na hetussa na sa hetukassa dhammassa ārammaṇa paccayena paccayaḥ
translated: A cause that is causally related is a condition, by way of cause condition, for a non-cause that is causally unrelated.

original: Hetu sahetuko dhammo nanahetussa nasahetukassa dhammassa ārammaṇapaccayena paccayo.🔽Hetu sahetuko dhammo nahetussa nasahetukassa ca nanahetussa nasahetukassa ca dhammassa
analyzed: hetu sa hetukaḥ dhammaḥ na na hetussa na sa hetukassa dhammassa ārammaṇa paccayena paccayaḥ  hetu sa hetukaḥ dhammaḥ na hetussa na sa hetukassa ca na na hetussa na sa hetukassa ca dhammassa
translated: A cause that is causally related is a condition, by way of object condition, for a non-cause that is causally unrelated.🔽A cause that is causally related is a condition, by way of object condition, for a non-cause that is causally unrelated.

original: ārammaṇapaccayena paccayo.
analyzed: ārammaṇa paccayena paccayaḥ
translated: A cause that is causally related is a condition, by way of object condition, for a non-cause that is causally unrelated and for a non-cause that is causally related.

original: Nahetu sahetuko dhammo nanahetussa nasahetukassa dhammassa ārammaṇapaccayena paccayo.
analyzed: na hetu sa hetukaḥ dhammaḥ na na hetussa na sa hetukassa dhammassa ārammaṇa paccayena paccayaḥ
translated: A non-cause that is causally related is a condition, by way of object condition, for a non-cause that is causally unrelated.

original: Nahetu sahetuko dhammo nahetussa nasahetukassa dhammassa ārammaṇapaccayena paccayo.
analyzed: na hetu sa hetukaḥ dhammaḥ na hetussa na sa hetukassa dhammassa ārammaṇa paccayena paccayaḥ
translated: A state without root-cause is related to a state without root-cause as object condition.🔽A state without root-cause is related to a state without root-cause and to a state with root-cause as object condition.

original: Nahetu sahetuko dhammo nahetussa nasahetukassa ca nanahetussa nasahetukassa ca dhammassa🔽ārammaṇapaccayena paccayo. (Saṅkhittaṁ.)
analyzed: na hetu sa hetukaḥ dhammaḥ na hetussa na sa hetukassa ca na na hetussa na sa hetukassa ca dhammassa  ārammaṇa paccayena paccayo saṅkhitta
translated: A state with root-cause and a state without root-cause are related to a state without root-cause as object condition.

original: Hetu sahetuko ca nahetu sahetuko ca dhammā nahetussa nasahetukassa dhammassa ārammaṇapaccayena
analyzed: hetu sa hetukaḥ ca na hetu sa hetukaḥ ca dhammā na hetussa na sa hetukassa dhammassa ārammaṇa paccayena
translated: A state with root-cause and a state without root-cause are related to a state with root-cause as object condition.

original: paccayo. Hetu sahetuko ca nahetusahetuko ca dhammā nanahetussa nasahetukassa dhammassa🔽ārammaṇapaccayena paccayo. (Saṅkhittaṁ.)🔽Hetuyā ekaṁ, ārammaṇe cha, adhipatiyā dve, anantare cattāri, sahajāte pañca, aññamaññe🔽cattāri, nissaye pañca, upanissaye cha, pacchājāte tīṇi, āsevane ekaṁ, kamme …pe…
analyzed: paccayaḥ hetu sa hetukaḥ ca na hetu sa hetukaḥ ca dhammā na na hetussa na sa hetukassa dhammassa  ārammaṇa paccayena paccayo saṅkhitta  hetuyā eka ārammaṇe cha adhipatiyā dve anantare cattāri sahajāte pañca aññamaññe  cattāri nissaye pañca upanissaye cha pacchājāte tīṇi āsevane eka kamme pe
translated: A state with root-cause and a state without root-cause are related to a state with root-cause and to a state without root-cause as object condition.

original: āhāre tīṇi, indriye pañca, jhāne tīṇi, magge pañca, sampayutte ekaṁ, vippayutte tīṇi
analyzed: āhāre tīṇi indriye pañca jhāne tīṇi magge pañca sampayutte eka vippayutte tīṇi
translated: In the root-cause section there is one triad and one dyad. In the object condition section there are six triads and one dyad. In the predominance condition section there are two triads and one dyad. In the proximity condition section there are four triads and one dyad. In the contiguity condition section there are four triads and one dyad. In the section on the prior condition there are five triads and one dyad. In the arising-together condition section there are five triads and one dyad. In the mutuality condition section there are four triads and one dyad. In the dependence condition section there are five triads and one dyad. In the support condition section there are six triads and one dyad. In the post-arising condition section there are three triads and one dyad. In the nutriment condition section there is one triad and one dyad. In the faculty condition section there are five triads and one dyad. In the absorption condition section there are three triads and one dyad. In the path condition section there are five triads and one dyad. In the association condition section there is one triad and one dyad. In the dissociation condition section there are three triads and one dyad.🔽In the presence condition section there are five triads and one dyad. In the absence condition section there are three triads and one dyad. In the disappearance condition section there are three triads and one dyad. In the non-disappearance condition section there are three triads and one dyad. In the root-cause condition section there is one triad and one dyad. In the fruit condition section there is one triad and one dyad. In the Nāga condition section there is one triad and one dyad. In

original: …pe… avigate pañca. (Pañhāvāraṁ vitthāretabbaṁ.)🔽Hetuṁ ahetukaṁ dhammaṁ paṭicca nahetu naahetuko dhammo uppajjati hetupaccayā.🔽Nahetuṁ ahetukaṁ dhammaṁ paṭicca nanahetu naahetuko dhammo uppajjati hetupaccayā … tīṇi. (Saṅkhittaṁ.)
analyzed: pe avigate pañca pañhāvāram  hetum ahetukam dhammam paṭicca na hetu na ahetukaḥ dhammaḥ uppajjati hetu paccayā  na hetum ahetukam dhammam paṭicca na na hetu na ahetukaḥ dhammaḥ uppajjati hetu paccayā tīṇi
translated: … in the inconsequential, five. (The section on questions should be elaborated in detail.)🔽With respect to a causally conditioned and causally unconditioned phenomenon, there arises a causally unconditioned and causally unconditioned phenomenon, having a cause as condition.🔽With respect to a causally unconditioned and causally unconditioned phenomenon, there arises a causally unconditioned and causally unconditioned phenomenon, having a cause as condition. … three. (The section on brief is finished.)

original: Hetuyā cattāri, ārammaṇe cattāri …pe… purejāte āsevane ekaṁ …pe… vipāke tīṇi …pe… avigate cattāri.
analyzed: hetuyā cattāri ārammaṇe cattāri pe purejāte āsevane ekam pe vipāke tīṇi pe avigate cattāri
translated: With respect to a cause, there are four. With respect to object, there are four. … With respect to the prenascent, there is one. … With respect to the postnascent, there is one. … With respect to nutriment, there are four. … With respect to the foundation of mind, there are four. … With respect to the dominant, there are four. … With respect to the prenascent, there is one. … With respect to the postnascent, there is one. … With respect to the prenascent and postnascent, there is one. … With respect to the prenascent and the decisive-support, there is one. … With respect to the postnascent and the decisive-support, there is one. … With respect to the prenascent and postnascent and the decisive-support, there is one. … With respect to the root cause, there are three. … With respect to the condition being a prior attainment, there is one. … With respect to the condition being a subsequent attainment, there is one. … With respect to the condition being a prior attainment and a subsequent attainment, there is one. … With respect to the condition being a prior attainment and the decisive-support, there is one. … With respect to the condition being a subsequent attainment and the decisive-support, there is one. … With respect to the condition being a prior attainment and a subsequent attainment and the decisive-support, there is one. … With respect to the condition being a prior attainment and the support, there is one. … With respect to the condition being a subsequent attainment and the support, there is one. … With respect to the condition being a prior attainment and a subsequent attainment and the support, there is one. … With respect to the condition being a prior attainment and the decisive-support and the support, there is one. … With respect to the condition being a subsequent attainment and the decisive-support and the support, there is one.
